sections.instructions: Create a clear, concise title that reflects the action's purpose, geographic scope, and primary sector(s). sections.instructions: Demonstrate how this action complements and builds upon other UNHCR and partner interventions. Address: (1) Linkages to UNHCR's broader country program and annual operational plan; (2) Complementarity with other ongoing or planned projects in the same geographic area or sector; (3) Lessons learned from previous similar interventions and how they inform this action; (4) Coordination mechanisms to avoid duplication or overlap with other actors; (5) Strategies to prevent double funding. Explain how this action fits within the broader humanitarian response architecture and UNHCR's multi-year strategy.

Provide detailed information on the most recent needs assessments that directly inform this proposal. ECHO is a NEEDS-BASED donor - this section is critical for justification. For each relevant assessment (maximum 2 years old, unless highly technical): (1) Date and name of assessment; (2) Lead organization(s) and whether it was joint/coordinated; (3) Methodology - who conducted it, sample size, data collection methods (surveys, focus groups, key informant interviews, etc.); (4) Type of data - primary vs. secondary sources; (5) Participation of affected populations in the assessment process. List ONLY assessments with DIRECT relevance to the proposed action. Demonstrate robust evidence base for the intervention.

Based on the assessments described above, provide a structured analysis of problems, needs, and risks within the intervention area and sectors. For each sector/population group, clearly articulate: (1) PROBLEMS - the humanitarian issues identified (with evidence/data from assessments); (2) NEEDS - what is required to address these problems; (3) RISKS - threats to the affected population if needs are not met. Include cause-and-effect relationships. Address vulnerability factors related to age, gender, disability, and diversity (AGDD). Consider environmental and climate-related trends. Use specific examples: 'Problem: 5% of child population are unaccompanied/separated children (UAM/SC); Need: Best interest determination, foster family identification, safe learning environments; Risk: UAM/SC face high risk of exploitation, smuggling, and trafficking.'

Justify why the proposed intervention is the most appropriate response to the identified problems, needs, and risks. Demonstrate clear linkage: 1 PROBLEM/NEED/RISK = 1 ELEMENT OF RESPONSE. For each problem identified in section 4.2, explain: (1) Why this specific response/modality is appropriate for the context; (2) How activities are adapted to local conditions and beneficiary preferences; (3) Why this approach is environmentally sound and meets Minimum Environmental Requirements (MER) - particularly regarding greening of non-food items (NFI); (4) How the response aligns with ECHO priorities and humanitarian principles; (5) Evidence or precedent supporting the effectiveness of this approach. Demonstrate strategic thinking and context-appropriate programming.

sections.section_name: Have you assessed this project as entailing data protection risks?
sections.section_label: 4.4. Have you assessed this project as entailing data protection risks?
sections.instructions: Assess and identify the operational scenario for data protection: Scenario 1 - The project involves neither the collection nor the processing of beneficiaries' personal data; Scenario 2 - The project relies on already collected data and existing processing, and will not result in the collection and/or processing of new data (essentially situations where there is no new influx/movement); Scenario 3 - The project will result in the collection and/or the processing of new data among the beneficiary populations (essentially situations where there is new influx/movement). State which scenario applies and reference UNHCR Data Protection Policy principles for compliance.

sections.section_name: Details of risk mitigation measures, including details of any planned Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA)
sections.section_label: 4.4.1. Details of risk mitigation measures, including details of any planned Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA)
sections.instructions: If Scenario 1 - Your project involves neither the collection nor the processing of beneficiaries’ personal data, mention Not Applicable. If Scenario 2 - The project relies on already collected data and existing processing, and will not result in the collection and/or processing of new data (= essentially situations where there is no new influx/movement); Scenario 3 - Theproject will result in the collection and/or the processing of new data among the beneficiary populations (= essentially situations where there is new influx/movement), then mention precisely -- Accountability structure: UNHCR Data Protection Policy establishes the notion of an internal Data Controller who bears accountability and responsibility within the organization for compliance with the Policy (including risk assessment and mitigation). Data controller’s role for projects is established on country, regional, or HQ level - depending on the territorial scope of the project. On country level, the role of Data controller belongs to country representative. - Data processing: UNHCR adheres to the 8 data protection principles established in the Policy for the collection and further processing of personal data of persons of concern. These principles are reflected in the key documents that guide UNHCR core mandate activities, including Guidance on Registration and Identity Management. - Risk assessment: The UNHCR Data Protection Policy and Guidance forms part of a risk management framework to identify and address the risks associated with the processing of personal data of persons of concern by UNHCR, its partners and other relevant third parties, and to outline appropriate mitigating measures. A Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) is part of this risk management framework and is foreseen for new technologies, systems for data processing, projects or policies, and data sharing arrangements that may negatively impact on the protection of personal data of UNHCR persons of concern. UNHCR employs internal tools to map operational data lifecycle and assess where the processing meets a threshold for DPIA. DPIA is required when developing new data processing systems and new technologies, and where collection and processing or sharing of personal data is likely to be large, repeated or structural; and for the sharing of particularly sensitive personal data with a third party. DPIA is strongly recommended for sharing of personal data with a partner or third party with presumed data protection weaknesses or where the level of data protection is difficult to assess. DPIA may be recommended in the processing of particularly sensitive personal data as defined in the Data Protection Guidance. The Data Controller determines the need for DPIA, oversees the assessment process, signs off on the report and makes decisions with regards to the data processing initiative and the necessary mitigating measures. - Risk mitigation: When sharing personal data of persons of concern with third parties, UNHCR employs technical and organisational measures to ensure security, confidentiality and integrity of personal data, and has procedures in place to assess whether the third party adheres to comparable standards. Data sharing agreements are entered into with third parties in cases where the sharing of personal data is large, repeated and structural.

Describe the specific criteria and methodology used to identify and select direct beneficiaries. For each sector, explain: (1) Targeting criteria - what makes individuals/households eligible (e.g., vulnerability scores, specific needs, demographic factors); (2) Selection process - how beneficiaries are identified and registered; (3) Verification mechanisms - how eligibility is confirmed; (4) Prioritization approach - if demand exceeds capacity, how are beneficiaries prioritized; (5) Inclusion/exclusion criteria for vulnerable groups. Reference any established Procedures for Targeting or vulnerability assessment tools used. Ensure transparency and accountability in beneficiary selection.

sections.fixed_text:
- Sex and Age disaggregated data: UNHCR applies an Age, Gender, and Diversity (AGD) approach to ensure inclusive programming and participation of women, children, older persons, and persons with disabilities emphasising inclusive programming and meaningful participation of displaced populations and ensuring targeted and effective responses to protection challenges. Participatory assessments and registration provide sex- and age-disaggregated data, informing project design and targeted responses to protection challenges.
 - Adapted assistance: UNHCR and partners profile women, men, boys, and girls to tailor assistance. Monthly dashboards such 5Ws, protection dashboard, etc. track civil documentation, support for vulnerable individuals, and border monitoring. UNHCR and partners strengthen GBV and child protection through awareness campaigns, PSEA measures, and referral pathways for legal, medical, and psychosocial services in BAY states. 
 - Prevention and mitigation of negative effects: AGD principles guide all sectors to prevent protection risks for vulnerable groups. UNHCR works with partners to assess capacity, implement PSEA, and ensure accountability and transparency, embedding inclusive approaches for women, children, older persons, and persons with disabilities in program design and delivery. 
 - Adequate participation: Meaningful participation is central to AGD. UNHCR engages men, women, boys, girls, persons with disabilities, and minority groups in GBV prevention, child protection, and decision-making. Efforts target underrepresented groups to promote inclusion and ensure community voices shape responses across all sectors.

sections.instructions: State the overall long-term IMPACT to which this action contributes. The principal objective must: (1) Match the relevant ECHO Humanitarian Implementation Plan (HIP) or financing decision; (2) Be formulated as a single statement starting with an infinitive verb; (3) Represent a broader goal that CANNOT be achieved by this action alone, but to which it contributes; (4) Be measurable through impact indicators. There should be only ONE principal objective per action. Example: 'To improve the protection environment for refugees and internally displaced persons in Chad.' This is the highest level of the results chain. It should be one concise, title-like impact statement (infinitive verb).

Describe the specific OUTCOME that this action will directly achieve for beneficiaries. The specific objective must: (1) Start with an infinitive verb; (2) Represent a change that CAN be achieved through this action within the timeframe; (3) Be more concrete and measurable than the principal objective; (4) Link directly to the results/outputs described in section 7.3. There should be only ONE specific objective. Provide a brief narrative (2-3 sentences) explaining how this objective will be achieved. Example: 'To strengthen the Government of Chad's capacity to provide protection and assistance to refugees through the development of a national asylum system. This will be achieved by providing technical support, training government officials, and establishing refugee status determination procedures.'

Select 1-2 SMART impact indicators (Key Outcome Indicators - KOI) that measure progress toward the specific objective. Choose from ECHO's pre-defined list: (1) % of beneficiaries reporting humanitarian assistance is delivered safely, accessibly, accountably, and participatively; (2) Crude Mortality Rate (deaths/10,000/day); (3) Average Coping Strategies Index (CSI); (4) % with acceptable Food Consumption Score (FCS); (5) Severe Acute Malnutrition Recovery rate; (6) Nutrition program coverage; (7) % of 6-23 month children receiving minimum acceptable diet (MAD); (8) % with adequate WASH services; (9) Case fatality rate; (10) % in safe/dignified shelters; (11) % of facilities with basic WASH; (12) % reduction in affected people; (13) CW/IED incidents; (14) % children retained in education; (15) % children transitioning in education; OR use custom indicators if more appropriate. MAXIMUM 2 impact indicators. Impact indicators MUST be in % or qualitative. For each indicator, provide: definition, baseline (with year/method), target (with units), source/method for data collection, and comments on standards/limitations.

sections.instructions: Define 1-5 distinct RESULTS (outputs/services) that will be delivered to achieve the specific objective. Subsectors should be selected from the list of ECHO subsectors: Protection/CP,Education/EiE,WASH,Health,Shelter,Nutrition,MPCA,DRR/DP,Mine action. Each result should: (1) Be formulated as an affirmative sentence (not an infinitive); (2) Represent a tangible output or service delivered; (3) Correspond to sectors identified in section 2.4; (4) Include Key Result Indicators (KRI) with baseline, target, and measurement method; (5) Have an estimated direct cost allocation. Maximum 5 results total. For regional actions, specify the country for each result. Consider using UNHCR outcomes/outputs from your country operational plan. Examples: 'The Government of Chad adopts a national asylum law' or 'A national refugee status determination system is established and operational in Chad.' For each result, provide: result title, expected outputs, indicators (compulsory/standard/custom KRIs), estimated budget, baseline/target/method.

List all critical conditions OUTSIDE UNHCR's control that must be in place BEFORE activities can begin. These are necessary starting conditions, not ongoing assumptions. Format as bullet points. For each precondition, be specific about: what must exist, who is responsible, and why it's necessary. Examples: (1) Sufficient core funding secured for the operation; (2) Adequate staffing levels approved and recruited; (3) Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) signed with host government; (4) Security clearance obtained for field access; (5) Partner agreements finalized. Distinguish preconditions from assumptions (section 7.5) - preconditions must exist before start, assumptions must hold during implementation.

sections.section_name: Assumptions and risks, including risk of fraudulent activities and environmental risk
sections.section_label: 7.5. Assumptions and risks, including risk of fraudulent activities and environmental risk
sections.instructions: Clearly distinguish and list both ASSUMPTIONS and RISKS. Format as bullet points with clear labeling. ASSUMPTIONS = POSITIVE factors OUTSIDE UNHCR's control that must hold true DURING implementation for success. Examples: (1) Government maintains open-border policy; (2) Security situation remains stable in neighboring countries; (3) Supply chains remain functional. RISKS = NEGATIVE factors OUTSIDE UNHCR's control that could jeopardize implementation if they materialize DURING the action. List ALL foreseeable risks including: fraud/corruption risks, environmental risks, conflict/security risks, climate-related risks, and other operational risks. Examples: (1) Escalation of violence preventing humanitarian access; (2) Diversion of assistance through corruption; (3) Natural disasters disrupting operations. Comprehensive risk identification helps justify under-implementation and can prevent reimbursement issues.

sections.section_name: Contingency measures taken to mitigate risks
sections.section_label: 7.6. Contingency measures taken to mitigate risks
sections.instructions: For each risk identified in section 7.5, describe specific, practical contingency measures. Follow the principle: 1 RISK = 1 CONTINGENCY MEASURE. For each contingency, explain: (1) What alternative approach will be used if the risk materializes; (2) What mitigation steps are already in place to reduce likelihood/impact; (3) What triggers will activate the contingency plan; (4) What resources or partnerships enable the alternative approach. Be concrete and actionable. Example: 'Risk: Escalation of violence in intervention areas. Contingency: (a) Establish remote management protocols with vetted local partners; (b) Pre-position emergency supplies in secure locations; (c) Activate when UN security phase reaches level 4; (d) Maintain communication through satellite phones and encrypted channels.'

Demonstrate how the proposed activities are informed by comprehensive risk and vulnerability analysis. Address the following elements: (1) Conflict analysis - how conflict dynamics, actors, and drivers have been assessed and inform activity design; (2) Environmental risks - identification of environmental hazards (floods, droughts, earthquakes, etc.) and how they affect intervention planning; (3) Climate risks - consideration of climate change impacts and climate variability on the target population and intervention; (4) Vulnerability mapping - how different population groups' vulnerabilities have been assessed and integrated into design. Explain how this analysis has shaped activity selection, timing, location, and implementation modalities to ensure appropriateness and effectiveness.

Explain how the action adopts do-no-harm and conflict sensitivity principles. Address: (1) Conflict sensitivity - how the action avoids exacerbating tensions, inequalities, or conflict dynamics; (2) Environmental do-no-harm - specific measures to minimize negative environmental impacts (waste management, resource use, pollution prevention); (3) Risk mitigation - how identified risks from section 8.1 are actively addressed and not worsened by the intervention; (4) Safeguarding mechanisms - measures to prevent unintended negative consequences on beneficiaries or communities. Provide concrete examples of how design choices reflect these principles (e.g., equitable beneficiary selection to avoid community tensions, environmentally sustainable material choices, culturally appropriate service delivery).

Describe specific measures to strengthen local capacities to prepare for, respond to, and adapt to identified risks. Address: (1) Individual capacity building - training, skills development, awareness-raising for affected populations; (2) Institutional strengthening - support to national/local government institutions, civil society organizations, or community structures; (3) Systems strengthening - improvements to local systems (early warning, emergency response, service delivery); (4) Sustainability - how capacity building ensures continued functionality after the action ends. Provide concrete examples: training local health workers, strengthening government coordination mechanisms, establishing community-based disaster preparedness committees. Explain how this contributes to reducing future humanitarian needs.

Demonstrate how the action contributes to longer-term solutions and links humanitarian-development-peace nexus. Address: (1) Transition strategy - how the action contributes to reducing humanitarian needs over time and supports transition to development programming; (2) Nexus approach - linkages or coordination with development actors, peacebuilding initiatives, or government development plans; (3) Sustainability mechanisms - how benefits/services will be maintained beyond the action period; (4) Exit strategy - planned handover to government, development partners, or community ownership. Identify specific development actors (World Bank, UNDP, bilateral development agencies) or national stakeholders involved in complementary longer-term interventions. Explain how this action creates conditions for or directly links to development solutions.

sections.fixed_text: UNHCR is committed to institutionalizing a culture of Accountability towards Affected People (AAP) beyond consultation with communities to an actual means of measuring the effectiveness and overall protection outcomes of multi-sectoral interventions. For UNHCR, AAP is outlined in its Age, Gender, and Diversity Policy (2018). Besides promoting participatory approaches to programming, our policy covers other key elements including Communication and Transparency, to ensure that forcibly displaced and stateless persons receive information in a timely manner, in their most preferred and accessible way, in order to mitigate protection risks and promote access to available services. Additionally, our policy highlights the importance of building effective feedback and response Mechanisms to ensure the appropriate management of forcibly displaced and stateless persons concerns and complaints - including those linked to fraud and sexual exploitation and abuse - and to adapt its programs, based on feedback received from people. UNHCR utilizes a diverse set of feedback and complaint mechanisms and tools in camps and urban areas. These include complaint and feedback boxes, information feedback points at community centers and networks of community-based structures. They enable forcibly displaced and stateless populations to communicate complaints and ideas regarding their experience of UNHCR or partner services and interventions. In addition, UNHCR and its partners are continuously investing in awareness raising among forcibly displaced populations about the available mechanisms for filing complaints and providing feedback to ensure that they can access these services and that they are provided in a satisfactory manner.

Monitoring is based on the reports and observations by the partners and local authorities and on regular direct observation and ongoing assessment by UNHCR (e.g. on the spot visits to project sites) and the comparison of achievements and related financial expenditures with objectives. Monitoring activities are carried out at various levels (camp, household) by partners and agencies implementing subprojects, UNHCR Branch Office, Sub Office and Field Offices. Situation reports are submitted by all UNHCR Field Offices to their respective Supervising Office on a monthly basis and Branch Offices submit a corresponding report to Headquarters.

sections.section_name: Coordination with national and local authorities
sections.section_label: Coordination with national and local authorities
sections.instructions: Describe coordination with national and local government authorities. Address: (1) Government engagement - coordination with relevant ministries (Interior, Social Affairs, Health, Education, etc.) and local authorities; (2) Alignment with national plans - how the action supports or aligns with national development plans, disaster management strategies, or refugee/IDP policies; (3) Capacity support - technical support or capacity building provided to government counterparts; (4) Inclusion in national frameworks - how the action is reflected in government-led coordination mechanisms or national appeals; (5) Transition planning - how activities will be handed over to government or integrated into national systems. Demonstrate respect for national sovereignty and support for government leadership in humanitarian response.

Describe coordination with development actors (World Bank, UNDP, bilateral development agencies, regional development banks). Address: (1) Development partnerships - coordination or collaboration with development organizations working in the same area/sector; (2) Nexus linkages - how this humanitarian action creates entry points for or complements development programming; (3) Joint analysis - shared assessments or planning with development actors; (4) Transition pathways - how the action facilitates transition from humanitarian to development approaches; (5) Inclusion in development frameworks - links to development plans, poverty reduction strategies, or Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Demonstrate strategic thinking about humanitarian-development nexus and longer-term solutions beyond immediate humanitarian response.

sections.section_name: Compulsory display of EU Humanitarian Aid visual identity on
sections.section_label: 12.1.1. Compulsory display of EU Humanitarian Aid visual identity on
sections.instructions: Confirm compliance with all 5 mandatory EU Humanitarian Aid visual identity requirements, or provide justification for any exemptions. Address each point: (A1) Building signage - EU/ECHO logos displayed on partner office buildings, health centers, distribution points, and other project facilities; (A2) Equipment - branding on vehicles, water tanks, containers, generators, and other visible equipment; (A3) Shipments and distributed goods - EU/ECHO visibility on blankets, sacks, tents, buckets, hygiene kits, cash/debit cards, and all items distributed to beneficiaries; (A4) Operational/outreach materials - branding on training materials, flyers, notebooks, posters, and beneficiary-facing communications; (A5) Staff clothing - EU/ECHO logos on T-shirts, field vests, caps, and other items worn by project staff. For each requirement, confirm implementation or provide detailed justification if exemption is needed (e.g., security concerns, cultural sensitivities, operational constraints). Attach photos or evidence as required.

sections.section_name: External communication of EU funding and partnership
sections.section_label: 12.1.2. External communication of EU funding and partnership
sections.fixed_text: To ensure visibility of ECHO's contribution, UNHCR will ensure ECHO's logo is included in UNHCR's multi-donor banners and other regular externally available publications, both in Arabic and English. Specific mentions to ECHO will be made on social media networks in accordance with UNHCR's internal policy on donor visibility. ECHO's logo will be placed in project locations funded through this contribution if security conditions permit. UNHCR will also remain available to facilitate meetings upon request of ECHO. ECHO's contribution will be further acknowledged in UNHCR's regular situation updates. In order to make communication and visibility activities as adequate as possible to respond to ECHO's expectations, UNHCR will liaise with ECHO Regional Information Office (RIO) and ECHO field office to discuss frequency, scope, schedule and channels to use for these activities. In Brussels, UNHCR visibility & communication team will be in regular contact with its ECHO counterparts to optimize the use of the outputs stemming from visibility & communication activities.

Describe any in-kind contributions. These are not included in total funding.

sections.fixed_text: The Executive Committee of the High Commissioner's Programme annually reviews UNHCR's programs for approval. Funding, however, depends almost exclusively on voluntary contributions outside those provided through the United Nations Regular Budget. UNHCR, thus, has no guaranteed level of income to cover all its approved and mandated activities. In addition, many voluntary contributions received by UNHCR either have no earmarking or are limited to a particular region/country. Such funds are thus allocated, as and when they are pledged and received, to the different operations according to requirements. Therefore, UNHCR can only state the identity of all donors to a specific operation once its annual accounts are closed. Information on the current year is published annually with UNHCR's Global Appeal (available on UNHCR web site. This proposal is for a multi-donor action, and as such, no overlap or double funding can occur, except in the unlikely event of the operation being over-funded with earmarked contributions. Should this event take place, UNHCR will consult with ECHO an appropriate action.

sections.instructions: Provide any additional information relevant to the appraisal of this proposal that does not fit in other sections. This may include: (1) Sensitive or confidential information affecting implementation; (2) Recent contextual changes not reflected elsewhere; (3) Specific challenges or constraints requiring ECHO awareness; (4) Innovative approaches or pilot activities; (5) Coordination agreements or partnerships still being finalized. For final reports, this section should include: (1) Overall assessment of achievement against objectives; (2) Specific difficulties encountered and how they were addressed; (3) Lessons learned and their implications; (4) Recommendations for future programming in this context/sector; (5) Reflections on what worked well and what could be improved. Be concise but comprehensive. Clearly mark any information that is sensitive or confidential.

Generate a comprehensive logframe table that captures: (1) Principal Objective, (2) Specific Objective, (3) Results (outputs/services delivered), (4) Activities (up to 10 per result), (5) Pre-conditions, (6) Assumptions, (7) Risks, (8) Contingency measures. For each result/objective, list all relevant KOI/KRI indicators, their full definitions, SMART baselines, targets (with units), sources/methods for data collection, and comments (standards used, other explanations). Ensure correct hierarchy and clarity: objectives at the top (1 per action, then specific, then result level), indicators per objective/result, with full consistency and correct cross-linkages. Use SMART, gender-disaggregated, and ECHO-compliant indicators wherever possible, referencing relevant Annex SF2/SF3/SF4. Present as a well-structured markdown or spreadsheet-style table with labeled column headings for all required fields (objective/result, indicator, baseline, target, source, assumption, risk, activity, etc.).
